**Babylon** ([𒆍](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%F0%92%86%8D
"wikt:𒆍")[𒀭](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%F0%92%80%AD
"wikt:𒀭")[𒊏](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%F0%92%8A%8F
"wikt:𒊏")[𒆠](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%F0%92%86%A0
"wikt:𒆠")KAN4.DIĜIR.RAKI [Akkadian](/wiki/Akkadian_language "Akkadian
language"): Bābili(m); [Aramaic](/wiki/Aramaic_language "Aramaic language"):
בבל, _Babel_ ; [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"): بَابِل‎,
_Bābil_ ; [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language"): בָּבֶל‎, _Bavel_
; [Classical Syriac](/wiki/Classical_Syriac_language "Classical Syriac
language"): ܒܒܠ‎, _Bāwēl_) was a key [kingdom](/wiki/Realm "Realm") in ancient
[Mesopotamia](/wiki/Mesopotamia "Mesopotamia") from the 18th to 6th centuries
BCE. The city was built on the [Euphrates](/wiki/Euphrates "Euphrates") river
and divided in equal parts along its left and right banks, with steep
embankments to contain the river's seasonal floods. Babylon was originally a
small [Akkadian](/wiki/Akkadian "Akkadian") town dating from the period of the
[Akkadian Empire](/wiki/Akkadian_Empire "Akkadian Empire") c. 2300 BC.

The town became part of a small independent [city-state](/wiki/City-state
"City-state") with the rise of the First [Amorite](/wiki/Amorite "Amorite")
Babylonian Dynasty in the nineteenth century BC. After the Amorite king
[Hammurabi](/wiki/Hammurabi "Hammurabi") created a short-lived empire in the
18th century BC, he built Babylon up into a major city and declared himself
its king, and southern Mesopotamia became known as [Babylonia](/wiki/Babylonia
"Babylonia") and Babylon eclipsed [Nippur](/wiki/Nippur "Nippur") as its holy
city. The empire waned under Hammurabi's son [Samsu-iluna](/wiki/Samsu-iluna
"Samsu-iluna") and Babylon spent long periods under
[Assyrian](/wiki/Assyrian_people "Assyrian people"), [Kassite](/wiki/Kassites
"Kassites") and [Elamite](/wiki/Elam "Elam") domination. After being destroyed
and then rebuilt by the Assyrians, Babylon became the capital of the short
lived [Neo-Babylonian Empire](/wiki/Neo-Babylonian_Empire "Neo-Babylonian
Empire") from 609 to 539 BC. The [Hanging Gardens of
Babylon](/wiki/Hanging_Gardens_of_Babylon "Hanging Gardens of Babylon") was
one of the [Seven Wonders of the Ancient
World](/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World "Seven Wonders of the Ancient
World"), although a number of scholars believe these were actually in the
Assyrian capital of [Nineveh](/wiki/Nineveh "Nineveh"). After the fall of the
Neo-Babylonian Empire, the city came under the rule of the
[Achaemenid](/wiki/Achaemenid "Achaemenid"), [Seleucid](/wiki/Seleucid_Empire
"Seleucid Empire"), [Parthian](/wiki/Parthian_Empire "Parthian Empire"),
[Roman](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire"), and
[Sassanid](/wiki/Sasanian_Empire "Sasanian Empire") empires.

It has been estimated that Babylon was the largest city in the world from c.
1770 – c. 1670 BC, and again between c. 612 – c. 320 BC. It was perhaps the
first city to reach a population above 200,000.[2] Estimates for the maximum
extent of its area range from 890[3] to 900 hectares (2,200 acres).[4]

The remains of the city are in present-day [Hillah](/wiki/Hillah "Hillah"),
[Babil Governorate](/wiki/Babil_Governorate "Babil Governorate"),
[Iraq](/wiki/Iraq "Iraq"), about 85 kilometres (53 mi) south of
[Baghdad](/wiki/Baghdad "Baghdad"), comprising a large
[tell](/wiki/Tell_\(archaeology\) "Tell \(archaeology\)") of broken mud-brick
buildings and debris.

The main sources of information about Babylon—excavation of the site itself,
references in [cuneiform](/wiki/Cuneiform "Cuneiform") texts found elsewhere
in Mesopotamia, references in the [Bible](/wiki/Bible "Bible"), descriptions
in classical writing (especially by [Herodotus](/wiki/Herodotus "Herodotus")),
and second-hand descriptions (citing the work of [Ctesias](/wiki/Ctesias
"Ctesias") and [Berossus](/wiki/Berossus "Berossus"))—present an incomplete
and sometimes contradictory picture of the ancient city even at its peak in
the sixth century BC.[5]

## Name[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section:
Name")]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Wiktionary-logo-en-v2.svg/40px-Wiktionary-logo-en-v2.svg.png) | Look up _**[𒆍𒀭𒊏𒆠](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%F0%92%86%8D%F0%92%80%AD%F0%92%8A%8F%F0%92%86%A0 "wiktionary:𒆍𒀭𒊏𒆠")**_ in Wiktionary, the free dictionary.  
---|---  
  
The English _Babylon_ comes from [Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek "Ancient Greek")
_Babylṓn_
([Βαβυλών](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%92%CE%B1%CE%B2%CF%85%CE%BB%CF%8E%CE%BD
"wikt:Βαβυλών")), a transliteration of the [Akkadian](/wiki/Akkadian_language
"Akkadian language") _Bābilim_.[6][_[not in citation
given](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_]

[Archibald Sayce](/wiki/Archibald_Sayce "Archibald Sayce"), writing in the
1870s, considered "Bab-ilu" or "Bab-ili" to be the translation of an earlier
[Sumerian](/wiki/Sumerian_language "Sumerian language") (formerly thought to
be in the obsolete "[Turanian](/wiki/Turanian_languages "Turanian languages")"
language-family) name "Ca-dimirra", meaning "gate of god",[7][8] based on the
characters KAN4 DIĜIR.RAKI (corresponding to the Sumerian phrase _kan diĝirak_
"god's gate") or perhaps based on other characters.[9]

According to Professor [Dietz-Otto Edzard](/wiki/Dietz-Otto_Edzard "Dietz-Otto
Edzard"), the city was originally called _Babilla_ , but by the time of the
[Third Dynasty of Ur](/wiki/Third_Dynasty_of_Ur "Third Dynasty of Ur"),
through a process of etymological speculation, had become _Bāb-ili(m)_ meaning
"gate of god" or "god's gate"[10] (Bab-[Il](/wiki/El_\(deity\) "El
\(deity\)")). The "gate of god" translation is increasingly viewed as a [folk
etymology](/wiki/Folk_etymology "Folk etymology") to explain an unknown
original non-Semitic placename.[11] Linguist [I.J. Gelb](/wiki/Ignace_Gelb
"Ignace Gelb") suggested in 1955 that _Babil/Babilla_ is the basis of the city
name, of unknown meaning and origin, as there were other similarly-named
places in Sumer, and there are no other examples of Sumerian place-names being
replaced with Akkadian translations. He deduced that it later transformed into
Akkadian _Bāb-ili(m)_ , and that the Sumerian _Ka-dingirra_ was a later
translation of that, rather than vice-versa.[12][13] [Joan
Oates](/wiki/Joan_Oates "Joan Oates") states in her book _Babylon_ that the
rendering _Gateway of the gods_ is no longer accepted by modern
scholars.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In the [Bible](/wiki/Bible "Bible"), the name appears as _Babel_
([Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language"):
[בָּבֶל](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D7%91%D7%91%D7%9C "wikt:בבל")‎,
_Bavel_ , [Tib.](/wiki/Tiberian_vocalization "Tiberian vocalization") בָּבֶל,
_Bāvel_ ; [Classical Syriac](/wiki/Classical_Syriac_language "Classical Syriac
language"): ܒܒܠ‎, _Bāwēl_), interpreted in the [Hebrew
Scriptures](/wiki/Hebrew_Scriptures "Hebrew Scriptures")' [Book of
Genesis](/wiki/Book_of_Genesis "Book of Genesis") to mean
"[confusion](/wiki/Confusion_of_tongues "Confusion of tongues")",[14] from the
verb _bilbél_ ([בלבל](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%9C
"wikt:בלבל"), "to confuse").[15] The modern English verb, to "babble", or to
speak meaningless words, is popularly thought to derive from this name, but
there is no direct connection.[16]

Ancient records in some situations use Babylon as a name for other cities,
including cities like [Borsippa](/wiki/Borsippa "Borsippa") within Babylon's
sphere of influence, and [Nineveh](/wiki/Nineveh "Nineveh") for a short period
after the Assyrian sack of Babylon.[17][18]

## Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Geography")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Babylone_site_fr.png/220px-
Babylone_site_fr.png)](/wiki/File:Babylone_site_fr.png)

[](/wiki/File:Babylone_site_fr.png "Enlarge")

Schematic showing Babylon on the Euphrates River with major areas within inner
and outer walls.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Babylon%2C_1932.jpg/220px-
Babylon%2C_1932.jpg)](/wiki/File:Babylon,_1932.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Babylon,_1932.jpg "Enlarge")

Babylon in 1932

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Ancient_Remains_in_Babylon.jpg/220px-
Ancient_Remains_in_Babylon.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ancient_Remains_in_Babylon.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ancient_Remains_in_Babylon.jpg "Enlarge")

Brick structures in Babylon, photographed in 2016

The remains of the city are in present-day [Hillah](/wiki/Hillah "Hillah"),[8]
[Babil Governorate](/wiki/Babil_Governorate "Babil Governorate"),
[Iraq](/wiki/Iraq "Iraq"), about 85 kilometers (53 mi) south of
[Baghdad](/wiki/Baghdad "Baghdad"), comprising a large
[tell](/wiki/Tell_\(archaeology\) "Tell \(archaeology\)") of broken mud-brick
buildings and debris. The site at Babylon consists of a number of mounds
covering an area of about 2 by 1 kilometer (1.24 mi × 0.62 mi), oriented north
to south,[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] along the [Euphrates](/wiki/Euphrates
"Euphrates") to the west. Originally, the river roughly bisected the city, but
the course of the river has since shifted so that most of the remains of the
former western part of the city are now inundated. Some portions of the city
wall to the west of the river also remain.

Only a small portion of the ancient city (3% of the area within the inner
walls; 1.5% of the area within the outer walls; 0.05% at the depth of Middle
and Old Babylon) has been excavated.[19] Known remains include:

  * Kasr—also called Palace or Castle, it is the location of the [Neo-Babylonian](/wiki/Neo-Babylonian "Neo-Babylonian") ziggurat [Etemenanki](/wiki/Etemenanki "Etemenanki") and lies in the center of the site.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * Amran Ibn Ali—the highest of the mounds at 25 meters, to the south. It is the site of [Esagila](/wiki/Esagila "Esagila"), a temple of [Marduk](/wiki/Marduk "Marduk") which also contained shrines to [Ea](/wiki/Ea_\(Babylonian_god\) "Ea \(Babylonian god\)") and [Nabu](/wiki/Nabu "Nabu").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * Homera—a reddish colored mound on the west side. Most of the [Hellenistic](/wiki/Hellenistic "Hellenistic") remains are here.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * Babil—a mound about 22 meters high at the northern end of the site. Its bricks have been subject to looting since ancient times. It held a palace built by Nebuchadnezzar.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Archaeologists have recovered few artifacts predating the Neo-Babylonian
period. The water table in the region has risen greatly over the centuries and
artifacts from the time before the [Neo-Babylonian Empire](/wiki/Neo-
Babylonian_Empire "Neo-Babylonian Empire") are unavailable to current standard
archaeological methods. Additionally, the Neo-Babylonians conducted
significant rebuilding projects in the city, which destroyed or obscured much
of the earlier record. Babylon was pillaged numerous times after revolting
against foreign rule, most notably by the [Hittites](/wiki/Hittites
"Hittites") and [Elamites](/wiki/Elamites "Elamites") in the 2nd millennium,
then by the [Neo-Assyrian Empire](/wiki/Neo-Assyrian_Empire "Neo-Assyrian
Empire") and the [Achaemenid Empire](/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire "Achaemenid
Empire") in the 1st millennium. Much of the western half of the city is now
beneath the river, and other parts of the site have been mined for commercial
building materials.

Only the Koldewey expedition recovered artifacts from the Old Babylonian
period. These included 967 clay tablets, stored in private houses, with
Sumerian literature and lexical documents.[19]

Nearby ancient settlements are [Kish](/wiki/Kish_\(Sumer\) "Kish \(Sumer\)"),
[Borsippa](/wiki/Borsippa "Borsippa"), [Dilbat](/wiki/Dilbat "Dilbat"), and
[Kutha](/wiki/Kutha "Kutha"). [Marad](/wiki/Marad "Marad") and
[Sippar](/wiki/Sippar "Sippar") were 60 km in either direction along the
Euphrates.[19]

## Sources[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Sources")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Dynastic_Chronicle.jpg/220px-
Dynastic_Chronicle.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dynastic_Chronicle.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Dynastic_Chronicle.jpg "Enlarge")

Illustration by [Leonard William King](/wiki/Leonard_William_King "Leonard
William King") of fragment K. 8532, a part of the [Dynastic
Chronicle](/wiki/Dynastic_Chronicle "Dynastic Chronicle") listing rulers of
Babylon grouped by dyansty.

Historical knowledge of early Babylon must be pieced together from epigraphic
remains found elsewhere, such as at [Uruk](/wiki/Uruk "Uruk"),
[Nippur](/wiki/Nippur "Nippur"), and [Haradum](/wiki/Haradum "Haradum").

Information on the Neo-Babylonian city is available from archaeological
excavations and from classical sources. Babylon was described, perhaps even
visited, by a number of classical historians including [Ctesias](/wiki/Ctesias
"Ctesias"), [Herodotus](/wiki/Herodotus "Herodotus"), [Quintus Curtius
Rufus](/wiki/Quintus_Curtius_Rufus "Quintus Curtius Rufus"),
[Strabo](/wiki/Strabo "Strabo"), and [Cleitarchus](/wiki/Cleitarchus
"Cleitarchus"). These reports are of variable accuracy and some of the content
was politically motivated, but these still provide useful information.[20]

### Early references[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Early references")]

References to the city of Babylon can be found in Akkadian and Sumerian
literature from the late third millennium BC. One of the earliest is a tablet
describing the Akkadian king Šar-kali-šarri laying the foundations in Babylon
of new temples for Annūnı̄tum and Ilaba. Babylon also appears in the
administrative records of the [Third Dynasty of Ur](/wiki/Third_Dynasty_of_Ur
"Third Dynasty of Ur"), which collected in-kind tax payments and appointed an
_[ensi](/wiki/Ens%C3%AD "Ensí")_ as local governor.[13][21]

The so-called [Weidner
Chronicle](/wiki/Babylonian_Chronicles#Provenanced_Chronicles "Babylonian
Chronicles") (also known as _ABC 19_) states that [Sargon of
Akkad](/wiki/Sargon_of_Akkad "Sargon of Akkad") (c. 23d century BC in the
[short chronology](/wiki/Short_chronology "Short chronology")) had built
Babylon "in front of Akkad" (ABC 19:51). A later chronicle states that Sargon
"dug up the dirt of the pit of Babylon, and made a counterpart of Babylon next
to Akkad". (ABC 20:18–19). Van de Mieroop has suggested that those sources may
refer to the much later Assyrian king [Sargon II](/wiki/Sargon_II "Sargon II")
of the [Neo-Assyrian Empire](/wiki/Neo-Assyrian_Empire "Neo-Assyrian Empire")
rather than Sargon of Akkad.[18]

The [Book of Genesis](/wiki/Book_of_Genesis "Book of Genesis"), chapter 10,
claims that king [Nimrod](/wiki/Nimrod "Nimrod") founded Babel, Uruk, and
Akkad.

### Classical dating[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Classical dating")]

[Ctesias](/wiki/Ctesias "Ctesias"), quoted by [Diodorus
Siculus](/wiki/Diodorus_Siculus "Diodorus Siculus") and in [George
Syncellus](/wiki/George_Syncellus "George Syncellus")'s _Chronographia_ ,
claimed to have access to manuscripts from Babylonian archives, which date the
founding of Babylon to 2286 BC, under the reign of its first king,
[Belus](/wiki/Belus_\(Babylonian\) "Belus \(Babylonian\)").[22] A similar
figure is found in the writings of [Berossus](/wiki/Berossus "Berossus"), who
according to Pliny,[23] stated that astronomical observations commenced at
Babylon 490 years before the Greek era of [Phoroneus](/wiki/Phoroneus
"Phoroneus"), indicating 2243 BC. [Stephanus of
Byzantium](/wiki/Stephanus_of_Byzantium "Stephanus of Byzantium") wrote that
Babylon was built 1002 years before the date given by [Hellanicus of
Lesbos](/wiki/Hellanicus_of_Lesbos "Hellanicus of Lesbos") for the siege of
Troy (1229 BC), which would date Babylon's foundation to 2231 BC.[24] All of
these dates place Babylon's foundation in the [[23rd century BC; however,
cuneiform records have not been found to correspond with these classical
(post-cuneiform) accounts.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Queen_of_the_Night_%28Babylon%29.jpg/220px-
Queen_of_the_Night_%28Babylon%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Queen_of_the_Night_\(Babylon\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Queen_of_the_Night_\(Babylon\).jpg "Enlarge")

The [Queen of the Night](/wiki/Burney_Relief "Burney Relief") relief. The
figure could be an aspect of the goddess [Ishtar](/wiki/Ishtar "Ishtar"),
Babylonian goddess of sex and love.

By around the [19th century BC](/wiki/19th_century_BC "19th century BC"), much
of southern Mesopotamia was occupied by [Amorites](/wiki/Amorites "Amorites"),
nomadic tribes from the northern [Levant](/wiki/Levant "Levant") who were
[Northwest Semitic](/wiki/Northwest_Semitic "Northwest Semitic") speakers,
unlike the native [Akkadians](/wiki/Akkadian "Akkadian") of southern
Mesopotamia and [Assyria](/wiki/Assyria "Assyria"), who spoke [East
Semitic](/wiki/East_Semitic_languages "East Semitic languages"). The Amorites
at first did not practice agriculture like more advanced Mesopotamians,
preferring a semi-nomadic lifestyle, herding sheep. Over time, Amorite grain
merchants rose to prominence and established their own independent dynasties
in several south Mesopotamian city-states, most notably [Isin](/wiki/Isin
"Isin"), [Larsa](/wiki/Larsa "Larsa"), [Eshnunna](/wiki/Eshnunna "Eshnunna"),
[Lagash](/wiki/Lagash "Lagash"), and later, founding Babylon as a state.

### Old Babylonian
period[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section:
Old Babylonian period")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Hammurabi%27s_Babylonia_1.svg/220px-

Linescan camera image of the cylinder seal above (reversed to resemble an

According to a Babylonian date list, [Amorite](/wiki/Amorite "Amorite")[a]
rule in Babylon began (c. 19th or 18th century BC) with a chieftain named
[Sumu-abum](/wiki/Sumu-abum "Sumu-abum"), who declared independence from the
neighboring city-state of [Kazallu](/wiki/Kazallu "Kazallu"). [Sumu-la-
El](/wiki/Sumu-la-El "Sumu-la-El"), whose dates may be concurrent with those
of Sumu-abum, is usually given as the progenitor of the [First Babylonian
Dynasty](/wiki/First_Babylonian_Dynasty "First Babylonian Dynasty"). Both are
credited with building the walls of Babylon. In any case, the records describe
Sumu-la-El’s military successes establishing a regional sphere of influence
for Babylon.[26]

Babylon was initially a minor city-state, and controlled little surrounding
territory; its first four Amorite rulers did not assume the title of king. The
older and more powerful states of [Assyria](/wiki/Assyria "Assyria"),
[Elam](/wiki/Elam "Elam"), [Isin](/wiki/Isin "Isin") and [Larsa](/wiki/Larsa
"Larsa") overshadowed Babylon until it became the capital of
[Hammurabi](/wiki/Hammurabi "Hammurabi")'s short lived empire about a century
later. Hammurabi (r. 1792–1750 BC) is famous for codifying the laws of
Babylonia into the _[Code of Hammurabi](/wiki/Code_of_Hammurabi "Code of
Hammurabi")_. He conquered all of the cities and city states of southern
Mesopotamia, including [Isin](/wiki/Isin "Isin"), [Larsa](/wiki/Larsa
"Larsa"), [Ur](/wiki/Ur "Ur"), [Uruk](/wiki/Uruk "Uruk"),
[Nippur](/wiki/Nippur "Nippur"), [Lagash](/wiki/Lagash "Lagash"),
[Eridu](/wiki/Eridu "Eridu"), [Kish](/wiki/Kish_\(Sumer\) "Kish \(Sumer\)"),
[Adab](/wiki/Adab_\(city\) "Adab \(city\)"), [Eshnunna](/wiki/Eshnunna
"Eshnunna"), [Akshak](/wiki/Akshak "Akshak"), [Akkad](/wiki/Akkad_\(city\)
"Akkad \(city\)"), [Shuruppak](/wiki/Shuruppak "Shuruppak"), [Bad-
tibira](/wiki/Bad-tibira "Bad-tibira"), [Sippar](/wiki/Sippar "Sippar") and
[Girsu](/wiki/Girsu "Girsu"), coalescing them into one kingdom, ruled from
Babylon. Hammurabi also invaded and conquered [Elam](/wiki/Elam "Elam") to the
east, and the kingdoms of [Mari](/wiki/Mari,_Syria "Mari, Syria") and
[Ebla](/wiki/Ebla "Ebla") to the north west. After a protracted struggle with
the powerful Assyrian king [Ishme-Dagan](/wiki/Ishme-Dagan "Ishme-Dagan") of
the [Old Assyrian Empire](/wiki/Old_Assyrian_Empire "Old Assyrian Empire"), he
forced his successor to pay tribute late in his reign, spreading Babylonian
power to Assyria's [Hattian](/wiki/Hattians "Hattians") and
[Hurrian](/wiki/Hurrian "Hurrian") colonies in [Asia Minor](/wiki/Asia_Minor
"Asia Minor").

After the reign of Hammurabi, the whole of southern Mesopotamia came to be
known as [Babylonia](/wiki/Babylonia "Babylonia"), whereas the north had
already coalesced centuries before into [Assyria](/wiki/Assyria "Assyria").
From this time, Babylon supplanted [Nippur](/wiki/Nippur "Nippur") and
[Eridu](/wiki/Eridu "Eridu") as the major religious centers of southern
Mesopotamia. Hammurabi's empire destabilized after his death. Assyrians
defeated and drove out the Babylonians and Amorites. The far south of
Mesopotamia broke away, forming the native [Sealand
Dynasty](/wiki/Sealand_Dynasty "Sealand Dynasty"), and the Elamites
appropriated territory in eastern Mesopotamia. The Amorite dynasty remained in
power in Babylon, which again became a small city state.

Texts from Old Babylon often include references to [Shamash](/wiki/Shamash
"Shamash"), the sun-god of Sippar, treated as a supreme deity, and
[Marduk](/wiki/Marduk "Marduk"), considered as his son. Marduk was later
elevated to a higher status and Shamash lowered, perhaps reflecting Babylon’s
rising political power[13]

### Middle Babylon[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Middle Babylon")]

In 1595 BC[b] the city was overthrown by the [Hittite
Empire](/wiki/Hittite_Empire "Hittite Empire") from [Asia
Minor](/wiki/Asia_Minor "Asia Minor"). Thereafter, [Kassites](/wiki/Kassites
"Kassites") from the [Zagros Mountains](/wiki/Zagros_Mountains "Zagros
Mountains") of north western [Ancient Iran](/wiki/Ancient_Iran "Ancient Iran")
captured Babylon, ushering in a dynasty that lasted for 435 years, until 1160
BC. The city was renamed Karanduniash during this period. Kassite Babylon
eventually became subject to the [Middle Assyrian
Empire](/wiki/Middle_Assyrian_Empire "Middle Assyrian Empire") (1365–1053 BC)
to the north, and [Elam](/wiki/Elam "Elam") to the east, with both powers
vying for control of the city. The Assyrian king [Tukulti-Ninurta
I](/wiki/Tukulti-Ninurta_I "Tukulti-Ninurta I") took the throne of Babylon in
1235 BC.

By 1155 BC, after continued attacks and annexing of territory by the Assyrians
and Elamites, the Kassites were deposed in Babylon. An Akkadian south
Mesopotamian dynasty then ruled for the first time. However, Babylon remained
weak and subject to domination by Assyria. Its ineffectual native kings were
unable to prevent new waves of foreign West Semitic settlers from the deserts
of the Levant, including the [Arameans](/wiki/Arameans "Arameans") and
[Suteans](/wiki/Suteans "Suteans") in the 11th century BC, and finally the
[Chaldeans](/wiki/Chaldea "Chaldea") in the 9th century BC, entering and
appropriating areas of Babylonia for themselves. The Arameans briefly ruled in
Babylon during the late 11th century BC.

### Assyrian period[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Assyrian period")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Sennacherib.jpg/220px-
Sennacherib.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sennacherib.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sennacherib.jpg "Enlarge")

Sennacherib of Assyria during his [Babylonian war](/wiki/Battle_of_Halule
"Battle of Halule"), relief from his palace in Nineveh

During the rule of the [Neo-Assyrian Empire](/wiki/Neo-Assyrian_Empire "Neo-
Assyrian Empire") (911–609 BC), Babylonia was under constant
[Assyrian](/wiki/Assyria "Assyria") domination or direct control. During the
reign of [Sennacherib](/wiki/Sennacherib "Sennacherib") of Assyria, Babylonia
was in a constant state of revolt, led by a chieftain named [Merodach-
Baladan](/wiki/Marduk-apla-iddina_II "Marduk-apla-iddina II"), in alliance
with the [Elamites](/wiki/Elamites "Elamites"), and suppressed only by the
complete destruction of the city of Babylon. In 689 BC, its walls, temples and
palaces were razed, and the rubble was thrown into the Arakhtu, the sea
bordering the earlier Babylon on the south. Destruction of the religious
center shocked many, and the subsequent murder of Sennacherib by two of his
own sons while praying to the god [Nisroch](/wiki/Nisroch "Nisroch") was
considered an act of atonement. Consequently, his successor
[Esarhaddon](/wiki/Esarhaddon "Esarhaddon") hastened to rebuild the old city
and make it his residence during part of the year. After his death, Babylonia
was governed by his elder son, the [Assyrian](/wiki/Assyria "Assyria") prince
[Shamash-shum-ukin](/wiki/Shamash-shum-ukin "Shamash-shum-ukin"), who
eventually started a civil war in 652 BC against his own brother,
[Ashurbanipal](/wiki/Ashurbanipal "Ashurbanipal"), who ruled in
[Nineveh](/wiki/Nineveh "Nineveh"). Shamash-shum-ukin enlisted the help of
other peoples subject to Assyria, including [Elam](/wiki/Elam "Elam"),
[Persia](/wiki/Persia "Persia"), [Chaldeans](/wiki/Chaldea "Chaldea") and
[Suteans](/wiki/Suteans "Suteans") of southern Mesopotamia, and the
[Canaanites](/wiki/Canaanites "Canaanites") and [Arabs](/wiki/Arabs "Arabs")
dwelling in the deserts south of [Mesopotamia](/wiki/Mesopotamia
"Mesopotamia").

Once again, Babylon was besieged by the Assyrians, starved into surrender and
its allies were defeated. Ashurbanipal celebrated a "service of
reconciliation", but did not venture to "take the hands" of
[Bel](/wiki/Bel_\(mythology\) "Bel \(mythology\)"). An Assyrian governor named
[Kandalanu](/wiki/Kandalanu "Kandalanu") was appointed as ruler of the city.
Ashurbanipal did collect texts from Babylon for inclusion in his extensive
[library](/wiki/Library_of_Ashurbanipal "Library of Ashurbanipal") at
Ninevah.[19]

After the death of Ashurbanipal, the Assyrian empire destabilized due to a
series of internal civil wars throughout the reigns of Assyrian kings [Ashur-
etil-ilani](/wiki/Ashur-etil-ilani "Ashur-etil-ilani"), [Sin-shumu-
lishir](/wiki/Sin-shumu-lishir "Sin-shumu-lishir") and
[Sinsharishkun](/wiki/Sinsharishkun "Sinsharishkun"). Eventually Babylon, like
many other parts of the near east, took advantage of the anarchy within
Assyria to free itself from Assyrian rule. In the subsequent overthrow of the
Assyrian Empire by an alliance of peoples, the Babylonians saw another example
of divine vengeance.[27]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Babylon_relief.jpg/220px-
Babylon_relief.jpg)](/wiki/File:Babylon_relief.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Babylon_relief.jpg "Enlarge")

Detail of the Ishtar Gate reconstruction

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Ishtar_Gate_at_Berlin_Museum.jpg/220px-
Ishtar_Gate_at_Berlin_Museum.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ishtar_Gate_at_Berlin_Museum.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ishtar_Gate_at_Berlin_Museum.jpg "Enlarge")

A reconstruction of the blue-tiled [Ishtar Gate](/wiki/Ishtar_Gate "Ishtar
Gate") which was the northern entrance to Babylon. It was named for the
goddess of love and war. Bulls and dragons, symbols of the god
[Marduk](/wiki/Marduk "Marduk"), decorated the gate.

Under [Nabopolassar](/wiki/Nabopolassar "Nabopolassar"), a previously unknown
Chaldean chieftain, Babylon escaped Assyrian rule, and in an alliance with
[Cyaxares](/wiki/Cyaxares "Cyaxares"), king of the [Medes](/wiki/Medes
"Medes") and [Persians](/wiki/Persian_people "Persian people") together with
the [Scythians](/wiki/Scythians "Scythians") and [Cimmerians](/wiki/Cimmerians
"Cimmerians"), finally destroyed the Assyrian Empire between 612 BC and 605
BC. Babylon thus became the capital of the Neo-Babylonian (sometimes and
possibly erroneously called the [Chaldean](/wiki/Chaldea "Chaldea"))
Empire.[29][30][31]

With the recovery of Babylonian independence, a new era of architectural
activity ensued, particularly during the reign of his son [Nebuchadnezzar
II](/wiki/Nebuchadnezzar_II "Nebuchadnezzar II") (604–561 BC).[32]
Nebuchadnezzar ordered the complete reconstruction of the imperial grounds,
including the [Etemenanki](/wiki/Etemenanki "Etemenanki")
[ziggurat](/wiki/Ziggurat "Ziggurat"), and the construction of the [Ishtar
Gate](/wiki/Ishtar_Gate "Ishtar Gate")—the most prominent of eight gates
around Babylon. A reconstruction of the Ishtar Gate is located in the
[Pergamon Museum](/wiki/Pergamon_Museum "Pergamon Museum") in
[Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin").

Nebuchadnezzar is also credited with the construction of the [Hanging Gardens
of Babylon](/wiki/Hanging_Gardens_of_Babylon "Hanging Gardens of Babylon")—one
of the [seven wonders of the ancient
world](/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World "Seven Wonders of the Ancient
World")—said to have been built for his homesick wife [Amyitis](/wiki/Amyitis
"Amyitis"). Whether the gardens actually existed is a matter of dispute.
German archaeologist [Robert Koldewey](/wiki/Robert_Koldewey "Robert
Koldewey") speculated that he had discovered its foundations, but many
historians disagree about the location. [Stephanie
Dalley](/wiki/Stephanie_Dalley "Stephanie Dalley") has argued that the hanging
gardens were actually located in the Assyrian capital, [Nineveh](/wiki/Nineveh
"Nineveh").[33]

Nebuchandnezzar is also notoriously associated with the [Babylonian
exile](/wiki/Babylonian_exile "Babylonian exile") of the Jews, the result of
an imperial technique of pacification, used also by the Assyrians, in which
ethnic groups in conquered areas were deported en masse to the capital.[34]

Chaldean rule of Babylon did not last long; it is not clear whether
[Neriglissar](/wiki/Neriglissar "Neriglissar") and [Labashi-
Marduk](/wiki/Labashi-Marduk "Labashi-Marduk") were Chaldeans or native
Babylonians, and the last ruler [Nabonidus](/wiki/Nabonidus "Nabonidus")
(556–539 BC) and his co-regent son [Belshazzar](/wiki/Belshazzar "Belshazzar")
were [Assyrians](/wiki/Assyrian_people "Assyrian people") from
[Harran](/wiki/Harran "Harran").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Persian conquest[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Persian conquest")]

In 539 BC, the Neo-Babylonian Empire fell to [Cyrus the
Great](/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great "Cyrus the Great"), king of [Persia](/wiki/Persia
"Persia"), with a military engagement known as the [Battle of
Opis](/wiki/Battle_of_Opis "Battle of Opis"). Babylon's walls were considered
impenetrable. The only way into the city was through one of its many gates or
through the Euphrates River. Metal grates were installed underwater, allowing
the river to flow through the city walls while preventing intrusion. The
Persians devised a plan to enter the city via the river. During a Babylonian
national feast, Cyrus' troops diverted the Euphrates River upstream, allowing
Cyrus' soldiers to enter the city through the lowered water. The Persian army
conquered the outlying areas of the city while the majority of Babylonians at
the city center were unaware of the breach. The account was elaborated upon by
[Herodotus](/wiki/Herodotus "Herodotus")[35][20] and is also mentioned in
parts of the Hebrew Bible.[36][37]

(Herodotus also described a moat, an enormously tall and broad wall cemented
with [bitumen](/wiki/Bitumen "Bitumen") and with buildings on top, and a
hundred gates to the city. He also writes that the Babylonians wear turbans
and perfume and bury their dead in honey, that they practice ritual
prostitution, and that three tribes among them [eat nothing but
fish](/wiki/Piscivore "Piscivore"). The hundred gates can be considered a
reference to [Homer](/wiki/Homer "Homer"), and following the pronouncement of
[Archibald Henry Sayce](/wiki/Archibald_Henry_Sayce "Archibald Henry Sayce")
in 1883, Herodotus’s account of Babylon has largely been considered to
represent Greek folklore rather than an authentic voyage to Babylon. Dalley
and others have recently suggested taking Herodotus’s account seriously
again.)[35][38]

According to [2 Chronicles](/wiki/Books_of_Chronicles "Books of Chronicles")
36 of the [Hebrew Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible "Hebrew Bible"), Cyrus later
issued a decree permitting captive people, including the [Jews](/wiki/Jews
"Jews"), to return to their own lands. Text found on the [Cyrus
Cylinder](/wiki/Cyrus_Cylinder "Cyrus Cylinder") has traditionally been seen
by biblical scholars as corroborative evidence of this policy, although the
interpretation is disputed because the text only identifies Mesopotamian
sanctuaries but makes no mention of Jews, Jerusalem, or Judea.

Under Cyrus and the subsequent Persian king [Darius I](/wiki/Darius_I "Darius
I"), Babylon became the capital city of the 9th Satrapy (Babylonia in the
south and Athura in the north), as well as a center of learning and scientific
advancement. In [Achaemenid](/wiki/Achaemenid "Achaemenid") Persia, the
ancient Babylonian arts of [astronomy](/wiki/Astronomy "Astronomy") and
[mathematics](/wiki/Mathematics "Mathematics") were revitalized, and
Babylonian scholars completed maps of constellations. The city became the
administrative capital of the [Persian Empire](/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire
"Achaemenid Empire") and remained prominent for over two centuries. Many
important archaeological discoveries have been made that can provide a better
understanding of that era.[39][40]

The early Persian kings had attempted to maintain the religious ceremonies of
[Marduk](/wiki/Marduk "Marduk"), but by the reign of [Darius
III](/wiki/Darius_III "Darius III"), over-taxation and the strain of numerous
wars led to a deterioration of Babylon's main shrines and canals, and the
destabilization of the surrounding region. There were numerous attempts at
rebellion and in 522 BC ([Nebuchadnezzar III](/wiki/Nebuchadnezzar_III
"Nebuchadnezzar III")), 521 BC ([Nebuchadnezzar IV](/wiki/Nebuchadnezzar_IV
"Nebuchadnezzar IV")) and 482 BC (Bel-shimani and Shamash-eriba) native
Babylonian kings briefly regained independence. However these revolts were
quickly repressed and Babylon remained under Persian rule for two centuries,
until [Alexander the Great](/wiki/Alexander_the_Great "Alexander the Great")'s
entry in 331 BC.

### Hellenistic
period[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section:
Hellenistic period")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Charles_Le_Brun_-
_Entry_of_Alexander_into_Babylon.JPG/416px-Charles_Le_Brun_-
_Entry_of_Alexander_into_Babylon.JPG)](/wiki/File:Charles_Le_Brun_-
_Entry_of_Alexander_into_Babylon.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Charles_Le_Brun_-_Entry_of_Alexander_into_Babylon.JPG "Enlarge")

"Entry of Alexander into Babylon", a 1665 painting by [Charles
LeBrun](/wiki/Charles_LeBrun "Charles LeBrun"), depicts Alexander the Great's
uncontested entry into the city of Babylon, envisioned with pre-existing
[Hellenistic architecture](/wiki/Ancient_Greek_architecture "Ancient Greek
architecture").

In October of 331 BC, [Darius III](/wiki/Darius_III "Darius III"), the last
[Achaemenid](/wiki/Achaemenid "Achaemenid") king of the Persian Empire, was
defeated by the forces of the [Ancient Macedonian](/wiki/Ancient_Macedonians
"Ancient Macedonians") [Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greece "Ancient Greece") ruler
[Alexander the Great](/wiki/Alexander_the_Great "Alexander the Great") at the
[Battle of Gaugamela](/wiki/Battle_of_Gaugamela "Battle of Gaugamela"). A
native account of this invasion notes a ruling by Alexander not to enter the
homes of its inhabitants.[41]

Under Alexander, Babylon again flourished as a center of learning and
commerce. However, following Alexander's death in 323 BC in the palace of
[Nebuchadnezzar](/wiki/Nebuchadnezzar "Nebuchadnezzar"), his empire was
divided amongst his generals, the [Diadochi](/wiki/Diadochi "Diadochi"), and
[decades of fighting](/wiki/Wars_of_the_Diadochi "Wars of the Diadochi") soon
began. The constant turmoil virtually emptied the city of Babylon. A tablet
dated 275 BC states that the inhabitants of Babylon were transported to
[Seleucia](/wiki/Seleucia_on_the_Tigris "Seleucia on the Tigris"), where a
palace and a temple ([Esagila](/wiki/Esagila "Esagila")) were built. With this
deportation, Babylon became insignificant as a city, although more than a
century later, sacrifices were still performed in its old sanctuary.[42]

### Renewed Persian
rule[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section:
Renewed Persian rule")]

Main article: [Babylonia §
Persian_Babylonia](/wiki/Babylonia#Persian_Babylonia "Babylonia")

Under the [Parthian](/wiki/Parthian_Empire "Parthian Empire") and [Sassanid
Empires](/wiki/Sassanid_Empire "Sassanid Empire"), Babylon (like Assyria)
became a province of these [Persian Empires](/wiki/Persian_Empire "Persian
Empire") for nine centuries, until after AD 650. It maintained its own culture
and people, who spoke varieties of [Aramaic](/wiki/Aramaic "Aramaic"), and who
continued to refer to their homeland as Babylon. Examples of their culture are
found in the [Babylonian Talmud](/wiki/Babylonian_Talmud "Babylonian Talmud"),
the [Gnostic](/wiki/Gnostic "Gnostic") [Mandaean](/wiki/Mandaeism "Mandaeism")
religion, [Eastern Rite](/wiki/East_Syrian_Rite "East Syrian Rite")
[Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity") and [the
religion](/wiki/Manichaeism "Manichaeism") of the prophet
[Mani](/wiki/Mani_\(prophet\) "Mani \(prophet\)"). Christianity was introduced
to Mesopotamia in the 1st and 2nd centuries AD, and Babylon was the seat of a
Bishop of the [Church of the East](/wiki/Church_of_the_East "Church of the
East") until well after the [Arab/Islamic
conquest](/wiki/Early_Muslim_conquests "Early Muslim conquests").

### Muslim conquest[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Muslim conquest")]

Main article: [Muslim conquest of Persia](/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia
"Muslim conquest of Persia")

In the mid-7th century, Mesopotamia was invaded and settled by the expanding
[Muslim](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") Empire, and a period of
[Islamization](/wiki/Islamization "Islamization") followed. Babylon was
dissolved as a province and [Aramaic](/wiki/Aramaic "Aramaic") and [Church of
the East](/wiki/Church_of_the_East "Church of the East") Christianity
eventually became marginalized. Ibn Hauqal mentions a small village called
Babel in the tenth century; subsequent travelers describe only ruins.[43]

Babylon is mentioned in medieval Arabic writings as a source of bricks,[19]
said to have been used in cities from Baghdad to Basra.[44]

European travelers in many cases could not discover the city's location, or
mistook [Fallujah](/wiki/Fallujah "Fallujah") for it. Twelfth-century traveler
[Benjamin of Tudela](/wiki/Benjamin_of_Tudela "Benjamin of Tudela") mentions
Babylon but it’s not clear if he really went there. Others referred to
[Baghdad](/wiki/Baghdad "Baghdad") as Babylon or New Babylon and described
various structures encountered in the region as the Tower of Babel.[45]
[Pietro della Valle](/wiki/Pietro_della_Valle "Pietro della Valle") found the
ancient site in the seventeenth century and noted the existence of both baked
and dried [mudbricks](/wiki/Mudbrick "Mudbrick") cemented with
[bitumen](/wiki/Bitumen "Bitumen").[44]

## Modern era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Modern era")]

From the accounts of modern travellers, I had expected to have found on the
site of Babylon more, and less, than I actually did. Less, because I could
have formed no conception of the prodigious extent of the whole ruins, or of
the size, solidity, and perfect state, of some of the parts of them; and more,
because I thought that I should have distinguished some traces, however
imperfect, of many of the principle structures of Babylon. I imagined, I
should have said: “Here were the walls, and such must have been the extent of
the area. There stood the palace, and this most assuredly was the tower of
Belus.” – I was completely deceived: instead of a few insulated mounds, I
found the whole face of the country covered with vestiges of building, in some
places consisting of brick walls surprisingly fresh, in others merely of a
vast succession of mounds of rubbish of such indeterminate figures, variety
and extent, as to involve the person who should have formed any theory in
inextricable confusion.

[Claudius J. Rich](/wiki/Claudius_Rich "Claudius Rich"), _Memoir on the Ruins
of Babylon_ (1815), pp. 1–2.[46]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/%D8%A3%D8%B3%D8%AF_%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%A8%D9%84_-_Lion_of_Babylon.png/220px-%D8%A3%D8%B3%D8%AF_%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%A8%D9%84_-_Lion_of_Babylon.png)](/wiki/File:%D8%A3%D8%B3%D8%AF_%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%A8%D9%84_-_Lion_of_Babylon.png)

[](/wiki/File:%D8%A3%D8%B3%D8%AF_%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%A8%D9%84_-_Lion_of_Babylon.png
"Enlarge")

[Lion of Babylon](/wiki/Lion_of_Babylon_\(statue\) "Lion of Babylon
\(statue\)")

The eighteenth century saw an increasing flow of travelers to Babylon,
including [Carsten Niebuhr](/wiki/Carsten_Niebuhr "Carsten Niebuhr") and
[Pierre-Joseph de Beauchamp](/wiki/Pierre-Joseph_de_Beauchamp "Pierre-Joseph
de Beauchamp"), as well as measurements of its latitude. Beauchamp’s memoir,
published in English translation in 1792, provoked the [British East India
Company](/wiki/British_East_India_Company "British East India Company") to
direct its agents in Baghdad and Basra to acquire Mesopotamian relics for
shipment to London.[47]

### Excavation and
research[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Excavation and research")]

[Claudius Rich](/wiki/Claudius_Rich "Claudius Rich"), working for the East
India Company in Baghdad, excavated Babylon in 1811–12 and again in
1817.[48][49] Robert Mignan excavated at the site briefly in 1827.[50]
[William Loftus](/wiki/William_Loftus "William Loftus") visited there in
1849.[51]

[Austen Henry Layard](/wiki/Austen_Henry_Layard "Austen Henry Layard") made
some soundings during a brief visit in 1850 before abandoning the site.[52]
[Fulgence Fresnel](/wiki/Fulgence_Fresnel "Fulgence Fresnel") and [Julius
Oppert](/wiki/Julius_Oppert "Julius Oppert") heavily excavated Babylon from
1852 to 1854. However, many of the fruits of their work was lost when a raft
containing over forty crates of artifacts sank into the Tigris river.[53][54]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Original_tiles_of_the_processional_street._Ancient_Babylon%2C_Mesopotamia%2C_Iraq..jpg/220px-
Original_tiles_of_the_processional_street._Ancient_Babylon%2C_Mesopotamia%2C_Iraq..jpg)](/wiki/File:Original_tiles_of_the_processional_street._Ancient_Babylon,_Mesopotamia,_Iraq..jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Original_tiles_of_the_processional_street._Ancient_Babylon,_Mesopotamia,_Iraq..jpg
"Enlarge")

Original tiles of the processional street. Ancient Babylon, Mesopotamia, Iraq.

[Sir Henry Rawlinson, 1st Baronet](/wiki/Sir_Henry_Rawlinson,_1st_Baronet "Sir
Henry Rawlinson, 1st Baronet") and [George
Smith](/wiki/George_Smith_\(Assyriologist\) "George Smith \(Assyriologist\)")
worked there briefly in 1854. The next excavation was conducted by [Hormuzd
Rassam](/wiki/Hormuzd_Rassam "Hormuzd Rassam") on behalf of the [British
Museum](/wiki/British_Museum "British Museum"). Work began in 1879, continuing
until 1882, and was prompted by widespread looting of the site. Using
industrial scale digging in search of artifacts, Rassam recovered a large
quantity of cuneiform tablets and other finds. The zealous excavation methods,
common at the time, caused significant damage to the archaeological
context.[55][56] Many tablets had appeared on the market in 1876 before
Rassam's excavation began.[19]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Mu%C5%A1%E1%B8%ABu%C5%A1%C5%A1u_%28sirrush%29_and_aurochs_on_either_side_of_the_processional_street._Ancient_Babylon%2C_Mesopotamia%2C_Iraq.jpg/220px-
Mu%C5%A1%E1%B8%ABu%C5%A1%C5%A1u_%28sirrush%29_and_aurochs_on_either_side_of_the_processional_street._Ancient_Babylon%2C_Mesopotamia%2C_Iraq.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mu%C5%A1%E1%B8%ABu%C5%A1%C5%A1u_\(sirrush\)_and_aurochs_on_either_side_of_the_processional_street._Ancient_Babylon,_Mesopotamia,_Iraq.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mu%C5%A1%E1%B8%ABu%C5%A1%C5%A1u_\(sirrush\)_and_aurochs_on_either_side_of_the_processional_street._Ancient_Babylon,_Mesopotamia,_Iraq.jpg
"Enlarge")

Mušḫuššu (sirrush) and aurochs on either side of the processional street.
Ancient Babylon, Mesopotamia, Iraq

A team from the [German Oriental Society](/wiki/Deutsche_Orient-Gesellschaft
"Deutsche Orient-Gesellschaft") led by [Robert Koldewey](/wiki/Robert_Koldewey
"Robert Koldewey") conducted the first scientific [archaeological
excavations](/wiki/Excavation_\(archaeology\) "Excavation \(archaeology\)") at
Babylon. The work was conducted daily from 1899 until 1917. Primary efforts of
the dig involved the temple of [Marduk](/wiki/Marduk "Marduk") and the
processional way leading up to it, as well as the city
wall.[57][58][59][60][61][62] Artifacts including pieces of the [Ishtar
Gate](/wiki/Ishtar_Gate "Ishtar Gate") and hundreds of recovered tablets were
sent back to Germany, where Koldewey's colleague [Walter
Andrae](/wiki/Walter_Andrae "Walter Andrae") reconstructed them into displays
at [Vorderasiatisches Museum Berlin](/wiki/Vorderasiatisches_Museum_Berlin
"Vorderasiatisches Museum Berlin").,[63][64] The German archaeologists fled
before [oncoming British troops](/wiki/Middle-Eastern_theatre_of_World_War_I
"Middle-Eastern theatre of World War I") in 1917 and again many objects went
missing in the following years.[19]

Further work by the [German Archaeological
Institute](/wiki/German_Archaeological_Institute "German Archaeological
Institute") was conducted by Heinrich J. Lenzen in 1956 and Hansjörg Schmid in
1962. Lenzen's work dealt primarily with the [Hellenistic](/wiki/Hellenistic
"Hellenistic") theatre, and Schmid focused on the temple ziggurat
[Etemenanki](/wiki/Etemenanki "Etemenanki").[65]

The site was excavated in 1974 on behalf of the Turin Centre for
Archaeological Research and Excavations in the Middle East and Asia and the
Iraqi-Italian Institute of Archaeological Sciences.[66][67] The focus was on
clearing up issues raised by re-examination of the old German data. Additional
work in 1987–1989 concentrated on the area surrounding the Ishara and
[Ninurta](/wiki/Ninurta "Ninurta") temples in the Shu-Anna city-quarter of
Babylon.[68][69]

During the restoration efforts in Babylon, the Iraqi State Organization for
Antiquities and Heritage excavation and clearing, but wider publication of
these archaeological activities has been limited.[70][71] Indeed, most of the
known tablets from all modern excavation remain unpublished.[19]

### Iraq government[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Iraq government")]

The site of Babylon has been a cultural asset to Iraq since the creation of
the modern Iraqi government in 1920. Babylonian images periodically appear on
Iraqi postcards and stamps. In the 1960s a replica of the Ishtar gate and a
reconstruction of Ninmakh temple were built on site.[72]

On 14 February 1978, the [Baathist](/wiki/Baathist "Baathist") government of
Iraq under [Saddam Hussein](/wiki/Saddam_Hussein "Saddam Hussein") began the
"Archaeological Restoration of Babylon Project": reconstructing features of
the ancient city atop its ruins. These features included the Southern Palace
of Nebuchandnezzar, with 250 rooms, five courtyards, and a 30-meter entrance
arch. The project also reinforced the Processional Way, the [Lion of
Babylon](/wiki/Lion_of_Babylon_\(statue\) "Lion of Babylon \(statue\)"), and
an amphitheater constructed in the city's Hellenistic era. In 1982 the
government minted a set of seven coins displaying iconic features of Babylon.
A [Babylon International
Festival](/w/index.php?title=Babylon_International_Festival&action=edit&redlink=1
"Babylon International Festival \(page does not exist\)") was held in
September 1987, and annually thereafter until 2002 (excepting 1990 and 1991),
to showcase this work. Proposed reconstruction of the Hanging Gardens and the
great ziggurat never took place.[73][72][74]

Hussein installed a portrait of himself and Nebuchadnezzar at the entrance to
the ruins and inscribed his name on many of the bricks, in imitation of
Nebuchadnezzar. One frequent inscription reads: "This was built by Saddam
Hussein, son of Nebuchadnezzar, to glorify Iraq". These bricks became sought
after as collectors' items after Hussein's downfall.[75] Similar projects were
conducted at [Nineveh](/wiki/Nineveh "Nineveh"), [Nimrud](/wiki/Nimrud
"Nimrud"), [Assur](/wiki/Assur "Assur") and [Hatra](/wiki/Hatra "Hatra"), to
demonstrate the magnificence of Arab achievement.[76]

When the 1991 [Gulf War](/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War") ended, Hussein wanted to
build a modern palace called Saddam Hill over some of the old ruins, in the
pyramidal style of a [ziggurat](/wiki/Ziggurat "Ziggurat"). In 2003, he
intended the construction of a [cable car](/wiki/Cable_car "Cable car") line
over Babylon, but plans were halted by the [2003 invasion of
Iraq](/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq "2003 invasion of Iraq").

occupation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: US and Polish occupation")]

Following the [2003 invasion of Iraq](/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq "2003
invasion of Iraq"), the area around Babylon came under the control of US
troops, before being handed over to [Polish
forces](/wiki/Polish_involvement_in_the_2003_invasion_of_Iraq "Polish
involvement in the 2003 invasion of Iraq") in September 2003.[77] US forces
under the command of General [James T. Conway](/wiki/James_T._Conway "James T.
Conway") of the [I Marine Expeditionary
Force](/wiki/I_Marine_Expeditionary_Force "I Marine Expeditionary Force") were
criticized for building the military base "Camp Alpha", with a
[helipad](/wiki/Helipad "Helipad") and other facilities on ancient Babylonian
ruins during the [Iraq War](/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq War"). US forces have
occupied the site for some time and have caused irreparable damage to the
archaeological record. In a report of the [British
Museum](/wiki/British_Museum "British Museum")'s Near East department, Dr.
John Curtis described how parts of the archaeological site were levelled to
create a landing area for helicopters, and parking lots for heavy vehicles.
Curtis wrote of the occupation forces:

> They caused substantial damage to the Ishtar Gate, one of the most famous
> monuments from antiquity [...] US military vehicles crushed 2,600-year-old
> brick pavements, archaeological fragments were scattered across the site,
> more than 12 trenches were driven into ancient deposits and military earth-
> moving projects contaminated the site for future generations of
> scientists.[78]

A US Military spokesman claimed that engineering operations were discussed
with the "head of the Babylon museum".[79] The head of the Iraqi State Board
for Heritage and Antiquities, Donny George, said that the "mess will take
decades to sort out" and criticised [Polish troops](/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces
"Polish Armed Forces") for causing "terrible damage" to the site.[80][81]
Poland resolved in 2004 to place the city under Iraq control, and commissioned
a report titled _Report Concerning the Condition of the Preservation of the
Babylon Archaeological Site_ , which it presented at a meeting on 11–13
December 2004.[73] In 2005 the site was handed over to the Iraqi Ministry of
Culture.[77]

In April 2006, Colonel John Coleman, former Chief of Staff for the 1st Marine
Expeditionary Force, offered to issue an apology for the damage done by
military personnel under his command. However, he also claimed that the US
presence had deterred far greater damage by other looters.[82] An article
published in April 2006 stated that UN officials and Iraqi leaders have plans
to restore Babylon, making it into a cultural center.[83][84]

Two museums and a library, containing replicas of artifacts and local maps and
reports, were raided and destroyed.[85]

### Present day[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Present day")]

In May 2009, the provincial government of [Babil](/wiki/Babil_Governorate
"Babil Governorate") reopened the site to tourists, but not many have come. An
oil pipeline runs through an outer wall of the city.[86][87]

## Cultural
importance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Cultural importance")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Nuremberg_chronicles_f_65r_3.png/220px-
Nuremberg_chronicles_f_65r_3.png)](/wiki/File:Nuremberg_chronicles_f_65r_3.png)

[](/wiki/File:Nuremberg_chronicles_f_65r_3.png "Enlarge")

Woodcut in 1493 _[Nuremberg Chronicle](/wiki/Nuremberg_Chronicle "Nuremberg
Chronicle")_ depicting the fall of Babylon.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/The_walls_of_Babylon_and_the_temple_of_Bel.png/220px-
The_walls_of_Babylon_and_the_temple_of_Bel.png)](/wiki/File:The_walls_of_Babylon_and_the_temple_of_Bel.png)

[](/wiki/File:The_walls_of_Babylon_and_the_temple_of_Bel.png "Enlarge")

"The Walls of Babylon and the Temple of Bel (Or Babel)", by 19th-century
illustrator [William Simpson](/wiki/William_Simpson_\(artist\) "William
Simpson \(artist\)")— influenced by early archaeological investigations.

Before modern archaeological excavations in Mesopotamia, the appearance of
Babylon was largely a mystery, and typically envisioned by Western artists as
a hybrid between ancient Egyptian, classical Greek, and contemporary Ottoman
culture.[88]

Due to Babylon's historical significance as well as references to it in the
[Bible](/wiki/Bible "Bible"), the word "Babylon" in various languages has
acquired a generic meaning of a large, bustling diverse city. Examples
include:

  * _Babylon_ is used in [reggae](/wiki/Reggae "Reggae") music as a concept in the [Rastafari](/wiki/Rastafari_movement#Zion_vs._Babylon "Rastafari movement") belief system, denoting the materialistic [capitalist](/wiki/Capitalist "Capitalist") world.
  * [Freemasonry](/wiki/Freemasonry "Freemasonry"), which has its own versions of biblical legends, classically considered Babylon as its birthplace and a haven for science and knowledge.[89]
  * _[Babylon 5](/wiki/Babylon_5 "Babylon 5")_ —a [science fiction](/wiki/Science_fiction "Science fiction") series about a multi-racial futuristic [space station](/wiki/Space_station "Space station").
  * _[Babylon A.D.](/wiki/Babylon_A.D. "Babylon A.D.")_ takes place in New York City, decades in the future.
  * [Babilonas](/wiki/Babilonas "Babilonas") ([Lithuanian](/wiki/Lithuanian_language "Lithuanian language") name for "Babylon")—a real estate development in [Lithuania](/wiki/Lithuania "Lithuania").

### Biblical
narrative[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Babylon&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Biblical narrative")]

In [Genesis
10:10](http://bible.oremus.org/?passage=Genesis+10:10–10:10&version=nrsv),
Babel (Babylon) is described as founded by [Nimrod](/wiki/Nimrod "Nimrod")
along with [Uruk](/wiki/Uruk "Uruk"), [Akkad](/wiki/Akkad_\(city\) "Akkad
\(city\)") and perhaps [Calneh](/wiki/Calneh "Calneh")—all of them in
[Shinar](/wiki/Shinar "Shinar") ("Calneh" is now sometimes translated not as a
proper name but as the phrase "all of them"). Another story is given in
Genesis 11, which describes a united human race, speaking one language,
migrating to Shinar to establish a city and tower—the [Tower of
Babel](/wiki/Tower_of_Babel "Tower of Babel"). God halts construction of the
tower by scattering humanity across the earth and confusing their
communication so they are unable to understand each other in the same
language.

Babylon appears throughout the [Hebrew Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible "Hebrew
Bible"), including several prophecies and in descriptions of the destruction
of Jerusalem and subsequent [Babylonian captivity](/wiki/Babylonian_captivity
"Babylonian captivity"). Consequently, in [Jewish](/wiki/Jewish "Jewish")
tradition, Babylon symbolizes an oppressor against which righteous believers
must struggle[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]. In [Christianity](/wiki/Christianity
"Christianity"), Babylon symbolizes worldliness and evil[90]. Prophecies
sometimes symbolically link the kings of Babylon with [Lucifer](/wiki/Lucifer
"Lucifer"). Nebuchadnezzar, sometimes conflated with Nabonidus, appears as the
foremost ruler in this narrative.[91]

The [Revelation of St. John](/wiki/Book_of_Revelation "Book of Revelation") in
the [Christian Bible](/wiki/Christian_Bible "Christian Bible") refers to
Babylon many centuries after it ceased to be a major political center. The
city is personified by the “[Whore of Babylon](/wiki/Whore_of_Babylon "Whore
of Babylon")”, riding on a scarlet beast with seven heads and ten horns, and
drunk on the blood of the righteous. Some scholars of [apocalyptic
literature](/wiki/Apocalyptic_literature "Apocalyptic literature") believe
this [New Testament “Babylon”](/wiki/Babylon_\(New_Testament\) "Babylon \(New
Testament\)") to be a [dysphemism](/wiki/Dysphemism "Dysphemism") for the
[Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire").[92]

  1. **Jump up ^** The Amorites were not native to Mesopotamia, but were semi-nomadic [Canaanite](/wiki/Canaanite_language "Canaanite language") [Northwest Semitic](/wiki/Northwest_Semitic "Northwest Semitic") invaders from the northern [Levant](/wiki/Levant "Levant"). They (together with the [Elamites](/wiki/Elamites "Elamites") to the east) had originally been prevented from taking control of the Akkadian states of southern Mesopotamia by the intervention of powerful [Assyrian](/wiki/Assyria "Assyria") kings of the [Old Assyrian Empire](/wiki/Old_Assyrian_Empire "Old Assyrian Empire") during the 21st and 20th centuries BC, intervening from northern Mesopotamia. However, when the Assyrians turned their attention to expanding their colonies in [Asia Minor](/wiki/Asia_Minor "Asia Minor"), the Amorites eventually began to supplant native rulers across the region.
  2. **Jump up ^** Please see [Chronology of the ancient Near East](/wiki/Chronology_of_the_ancient_Near_East "Chronology of the ancient Near East") for more discussion on dating events in the [2nd millennium BC](/wiki/2nd_millennium_BC "2nd millennium BC"), including the Sack of Babylon.

  34. **Jump up ^** Seymour (2006), pp. 88–89. “Preventing uprisings on the fringes of the empire was a major concern for Assyrian kings, and a number of policies developed to meet this need, among them mass deportations. When new territory was conquered or a rebellious vassal crushed, an increased imperial presence in the trouble spot was often complemented by the removal of large numbers of the indigenous population to the imperial core, effectively breaking up the rebellious population and reducing the potential for future resistance. This practice was effective, and continued throughout the Neo-Assyrian and Neo-Babylonian empires until 539 BC and Cyrus’s conquest of Babylon. The majority of the immigrant population were not slaves (Yamauchi 2002: 365), and some did rise to high status positions at the core of the empire (a possibility reflected in the career of the biblical Daniel, who rises to the status of trusted royal confidant).”
